content:
IMO the "Quote and reply or forward" phrasing in the triple dot menu on messages is confusing and overly verbose, especially since there's no way to "forward" a message as a PM (yet).

How would we feel about changing it to "Quote and reply", "Quote message", or just "Quote"?
Also, how would we feel about using the fa-quote-left icon instead of the current arrow-style icon?
(IIRC the NYT/wirecutter people were confused about this, and thought that was the only way to reply to a message, so I think removing "Reply" from that option would be good, and changing the icon)

Any of those shorter versions definitely sounds like an improvement.

FWIW GitHub calls their corresponding option "Quote reply".

"Quote reply" is concise but possibly confusing/ambiguous until you're used to it - not a "reply" action but a "quote reply" action? Am I quoting another reply?
The only text ZT has is a fairly long help text of Reply quoting the current message text; we could certainly do another iteration on that there, but a shortened form of that such as Reply quoting this message seems good.
For context, the web app appears to have Quote and reply to message in the help text, so it seems good to synchronize those to some extent in any case.

/poll Name the button:

  • Quote
  • Quote message
  • Quote and reply
  • Quote and reply or forward

The "forward" text was added to it since users were finding it difficult to know how to forward messages. Since Quote is a good way to forward messages too, this solves the issue. We haven't heard any complaints from users since then about this afaik.

The non-intuitive way to copy and forward messages is to view the message source and then copy the message. This is not known to many users and trying to copy just text using cursor drag doesn't preserve formatting.

Hmmm, interesting. Is that a common thing that people want to do? I'd be curious to see where we got the feedback that that was too difficult.

This thread is a result of hearing some folks at a company that uses Zulip being confused about what "forward" meant in this context on a social call. They thought it meant that it would let you PM someone the message, which isn't even really true, since we don't let you switch from a topic composebox to a PM composebox with the same message content.

My guess is that this is people that are used to WhatsApp? Are there other messaging apps that have "forward" as a common thing?

Wesley Aptekar-Cassels said:

Also, how would we feel about using the fa-quote-left icon instead of the current arrow-style icon?

It's good to have the symbol reachable on the keyboard, though. I have a habit of copying parts of messages and pre-pending them with the > symbol to reference and then answer a particular point in a message. Maybe you could preserve the function of the > symbol alongside the new one.

As an aside, being able to properly quote part of a message (by referencing the original author) would be nice, though I can't think of a way to do this. You'd want to highlight some text and them reach for a quote and reply function that targets just the highlighted text. Mostly, I always want to avoid recursive quoting which I find confusing and unsightly.

Plankter said:

As an aside, being able to properly quote part of a message (by referencing the original author) would be nice, though I can't think of a way to do this. You'd want to highlight some text and them reach for a quote and reply function that targets just the highlighted text.

I agree this would be a handy feature for our "quote" option to have.

GitHub's "Quote reply" option does exactly that: if you've selected part of the message first, it'll only quote that part, instead of the whole thing. I use that feature regularly.

Wesley Aptekar-Cassels said:

Also, how would we feel about using the fa-quote-left icon instead of the current arrow-style icon?

Good thought -- I agree this would be good too. The current icon suggests "reply", and that one would be much better for "quote" which is really what this option is about.

Plankter said:

It's good to have the symbol reachable on the keyboard, though. I have a habit of copying parts of messages and pre-pending them with the > symbol to reference and then answer a particular point in a message. Maybe you could preserve the function of the > symbol alongside the new one.

(I don't think Wesley is suggesting changing the keyboard shortcut -- rather it's about the icon at the left of the option:)
image.png
Indeed, sorry!

Aman Agrawal said:

The "forward" text was added to it since users were finding it difficult to know how to forward messages.

What does the forward operation do?

Greg Price said:
if you've selected part of the message first, it'll only quote that part, instead of the whole thing. I use that feature regularly.

This is something we intend to add; it's blocked on technical issues with browser selection that I don't want to get into here, because it's independent of the main question here.

Plankter said:

As an aside, being able to properly quote part of a message (by referencing the original author) would be nice, though I can't think of a way to do this. You'd want to highlight some text and them reach for a quote and reply function that targets just the highlighted text. Mostly, I always want to avoid recursive quoting which I find confusing and unsightly.

You can do this today somewhat awkwardly by quoting the message and then deleting parts of what the other person sent to just the parts you want to reply to.

The "Forward" use case is a thing I use on a regular basis and is not discoverable enough -- it's basically do "quote-and-reply" and then change the recipient. I think ultimately we want some better mechanism for teaching this idea than this. We had "Quote and reply" as the name before last summer.

It's also worth mentioning that we will probably add some sort of "Quote and reply to new topic" more first-class feature that might do backlinks for you, and probably that would end up removing the "or forward" from the name.
(So I think it's reasonable to remove "or forward" part of this label given that we plan to add something better for that problem.)
"Quote" is the most popular in the poll, so I'll file a PR changing that and the icon.
Err, wait, it's tied between "Quote" and "Quote and reply"
#18756

I worry that just "Quote" is unclear about what that's going to do to someone who's never used it before (I could imagine someone thinking it copied the message or something). As a sidenote, this is also the one of the only two strings we have that include the word "reply" in the message UI (the other being "Reply mentioning user" in the avatar menu.

So that was my motivation for preferring "Quote and reply".

Yeah, I can see either way. My preference for "Quote" is both since it's shorter (which I think makes the three-dot menu easier to skim), and because I think "and reply" caused this sort of confusion.

@wirecutter @melaniepinola thanks for including @zulip in your review of team chat apps (https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/best-team-messaging-app/). However, your review completely misrepresents Zulip's threading model by claiming "every reply quotes the original message".

- Zulip chat for distributed teams (@zulip)

I think that confusion was caused by something else, which is that they were specifically trying to check if Zulip had copied Slack's threading feature, and this was the closest thing to Slack-style threads that they could find in 5 minutes (you can grab an old copy of the article from archive.org to check if my memory is correct).
Oh, interesting, that makes sense :/

My preference is still for "Quote", since it's shorter/easier to skim and I don't think it's something where someone who's looking for it wouldn't find it without the "and reply", but perhaps it's not as confusing as I'd thought.

My mental model is that most people find out about this feature from seeing other people use it, so I think people usually have an idea of what it's going to do formed before they click it, but I could be wrong about that.
Well, that's true in an existing organization, but one also needs to think about the new organization onboarding experience.

Another variation would be "Quote reply" -- that's what GitHub uses.

It's a bit more concise / easier to skim than "Quote and reply", and I think gives much the same hint about what it's going to do.

"Quote and reply" is not that long and accurately describes the chaining of two operations. I have observed many conference attendees, most new to Zulip, use this like the air they breath, so I get the feeling there is no problem to solve here.

When Vlad Korobov and I chatted the other day, he proposed splitting the "Quote and reply or forward" message menu option into two separate options:

  1. "Quote and reply", which would have the same functionality as the current option.
  2. "Forward", which would put the same content into the compose box, but change the recipient to be "DM", and (I think) put the cursor into the addressee field.

Thoughts? I haven't re-read this thread carefully, but I certainly agree with the initial feedback that the current option is not easy to parse/understand.
I actually just wrote up forwarding instructions the other day, inspired by the fact that you can now easily switch to sending a DM: https://chat.zulip.org/help/quote-and-reply#forward-a-message

I agree with the idea. When I first encountered the new menu style, the first line felt kind of overwhelming. I also expected "edit message" to be the first line, but that was just a lot of muscle memory, and I don't necessarily think the change there is bad--I am just giving context.

The reason we went with "Quote and reply or forward" was that the menu is already really tall with a bunch of options, and long menus tend to create a feeling of it being overwhelming and hard to find things.
We've already made the menu taller by splitting "move message" and "edit message", and I think once you get up to ~10 items in menu, the menus become really hard to visually skim.

We've at times discussed some ideas for making the menu more compact/icon focused, like maybe moving edit/move/delete to a row of icons; maybe we should think about that design direction if we want to take a menu item and turn it into two identical things.
Another option would be to just remove the "or forward" text and just have it say "Quote and reply", and just treat forwarding as an advanced thing you figure out how to do after quoting a message.

I don't really share your concern about overly tall menus on the same visceral level, although I totally understand the logic. The gear menu is also getting kind of tall.

I think I support the short-term idea here to just remove "or forward". It certainly never added any clarity for me.
"Quote and reply" has always made perfect sense to me. As much as I appreciate Zulip's connection to email, I have never ever, ever thought of myself as forwarding a message.

When it comes to metaphors for understanding Zulip, l usually think more in terms of "mailing lists" than "email", so the concept of "cross-posting" comes up more often in my brain than the idea of "forwarding".
Obviously, the "mailing list" metaphor may be becoming too ancient to be useful, but that's how my brain works.

• We are not yet on 10 items in the menu
    image.png

  • submenues is an appropriate thing later

  • forwarding might be pretty popular option

  • for some reason I have emoji option there while I already have it in quick actions
    image.png, there is no star message menu option

  • event a separate keyboard option for forwarding deserves a key (reply is Shift ., forward could be Shift F or any other)
I think it's a good idea to remove the emoji option as Vlad suggests. It not only has its own icon, but it has its own relatively easy-to-remember hotkey.

As a quick aside, it appears that I can react to my own message with the hotkey and the interactive menu, but Zulip doesn't hover the emoji icon. It's a little strange to react to your own message, but YouTube lets you like your own video, and I think there are sort of funny times in Zulip where you would react to your own messages. Also practical times, just for learning the app.
You can see my self-reactions above. ^^^ (one with :, and the other via the menu)
(and a third self-reaction above with the + key)
I don't think this is super important, but it appears to be a completely unintentional inconsistency.
If it's what I think you mean, it substitutes the edit 'pencil' instead, for messages you've written yourself?

Neil Pilgrim (neiljp) said:

If it's what I think you mean, it substitutes the edit 'pencil' instead, for messages you've written yourself?

Yup, basically the current behavior seems to be that you get pencil for your messages, smiley for their messages, but not smiley for your messages. The current behavior doesn't seem to be driven by any screen real estate concerns.

There is obviously a certain amount of logic that says that you would never react to your own messages, but if you accept that premise, it should be applied consistently. I personally think you should be able to self-react despite the weirdness of it during most circumstances.
There is a cost to extra items in the space to the left of the timestamp -- it creates empty space in the message body for every message you are not hovering over.

Vlad Korobov said:

  • We are not yet on 10 items in the menu

We would be at 10 for a message you yourself sent if we added this for administrators, at least:
image.png
(Many of the options have conditionals to only offer them to some users)

We technically could remove "Edit message" from that menu for messages you sent, and remove "add emoji reaction" for messages someone else sent if we are displaying those icons outside the menu, but doing so has significant downsides; I think "Edit message" in particular would be annoying to not display in the same area as "Move message" and "Delete message".

Tim Abbott said:

There is a cost to extra items in the space to the left of the timestamp -- it creates empty space in the message body for every message you are not hovering over.

Oh, I see. If you send a bunch of messages in a row, then the second, third, fourth, etc. messages cause that constraint.
(For the first message, you have basically unlimited space on the top row.)

As another aside, I will say that I find all these icons more distracting than helpful. I am sure I am in the minority here, but I doubt I am the only person:

image.png
It is definitely odd that Zulip has icon representations for all the things that you can do from the menu, but the three icons that show up when you hover aren't the top icons in the menu.
And then back to Vlad's point, why is smiley in the menu but star not?
And if quote/reply is the most important feature for the interactive menu, why don't we have that convenience icon upon hover?

And then it's also funny that the most important thing you can do with a message is reply to it, and that shows up neither as a hoverable icon nor an item in the menu, and then how are people supposed to learn the hotkey without going into the keyboard help menu (totally out of context)?

Just in terms of removing design constraints and thinking out of the box, remember that there is no law that every popup menu has to be a single column of options. It's certainly more conventional to have menus be single-column, but if there are enough options in a menu to warrant multiple columns, then building a multi-column menu should at least get some consideration.
especially insofar as the menus are, at least for some people, just training tools to direct people to hotkey shortcuts
but even for mouse users, you just need a nice layout and a click target
The "Add emoji reaction" item in the menu doesn't show the ":" as the shortcut for some reason. The option to "Mark as unread from here" shows the hotkey as "U" instead of shift-U.

Steve Howell said:

It is definitely odd that Zulip has icon representations for all the things that you can do from the menu, but the three icons that show up when you hover aren't the top icons in the menu.

This is intentional; the items in the menu are organized by groupings around what type of thing they are; I find that organization quite helpful. And as has been discussed above, we don't necessarily intend to always show 3 items available on hover in the menu.

(I would be very much opposed to putting "star" in the menu, for example, because it'd just be clutter given the very clean UI for toggling and display being in the same place that it already has)

I've generally been leaning in the direction that we could make the menus have more space by having several icons in a row for say, edit/move/delete (without the words); it's a bit of a tricky design problem with things like keyboard navigation, but it might be possible to make it work.

Tim Abbott said:

I've generally been leaning in the direction that we could make the menus have more space by having several icons in a row for say, edit/move/delete (without the words); it's a bit of a tricky design problem with things like keyboard navigation, but it might be possible to make it work.

I think that's a useful direction (and I do appreciate that it has some challenges).

Steve Howell said:

The "Add emoji reaction" item in the menu doesn't show the ":" as the shortcut for some reason. The option to "Mark as unread from here" shows the hotkey as "U" instead of shift-U.

The first part seems like a bug/omission; the second is intentional; the popovers design at present does not have space for Shift U, so those are case-sensitive pending a redesign of the popover visuals to support the more explicit keyboard shortcut hint style.

I would file an issue to simply add the the hotkey tip for "Add emoji reaction" in the menu, but I think there's some logic in just omitting it from the menu insofar as you want to de-clutter the menu and continue to keep "Star message" out of the menu. (And, again, I am just agreeing with Vlad here.)

Tim Abbott said:

Another option would be to just remove the "or forward" text and just have it say "Quote and reply", and just treat forwarding as an advanced thing you figure out how to do after quoting a message.

I think this would be a good improvement.

I agree with the concern that the menu is getting long already, enough to diminish the discoverability of all the items in it.

Steve Howell said:

I would file an issue to simply add the the hotkey tip for "Add emoji reaction" in the menu, but I think there's some logic in just omitting it from the menu insofar as you want to de-clutter the menu and continue to keep "Star message" out of the menu. (And, again, I am just agreeing with Vlad here.)

Yes, we should do both. Improve "Add emoji reaction" three-dot menu option #25602
I should probably have noted that we want to test adding a "Quote and reply" hover button (#23100 / PR #23100).

Greg Price said:

Tim Abbott said:

Another option would be to just remove the "or forward" text and just have it say "Quote and reply", and just treat forwarding as an advanced thing you figure out how to do after quoting a message.

I think this would be a good improvement.

OK, that sounds like a good next step. I filed Rename "Quote and reply or forward" to "Quote and reply" #25603; should be a quick one for someone to take care of.
(I don't know if there are any changes in variable names, etc. that should go along with this?)
I'll grab this one.
I found it interesting just now that other pages in the help center (except for the one that explicitly describes the menu option) always just refer to this functionality as "Quote and reply".
I noticed that, too, Alya!
Opened #25606 with these changes.

I went ahead and fixed up the internationalization tests, too, including the French example. I hope that wasn't an overzealous fix, but I'm guessing the translation files will take time to reflect this?

Alya Abbott said:

Yes, we should do both. Improve "Add emoji reaction" three-dot menu option #25602

It turns out that the emoji item had been supposed to have the behavior specified here, and this regressed due to a broken selector.
In any case, #25606 is now merged, so the menu is a bit shorter for messages you didn't yourself send.
